Replies.Reply: Then what are you doing here?
Then why would he throw himself out a window?
Karen nods.   Maria's brave face slips.   She turns away.
I put all this behind me. I don't want to open it back up again.
Because I can't leave. I tried.
He usually didn't wake up before me. But that morning, he did. He made coffee for us. Then he sat there and waited for me to wake up.
Look. I've had the police up here, I talked with Detectives, I even hired a P.I.--
I don't know what you're going through, or what you think you know about my husband. But I don't have any answers. I'm sorry.
This is all his stuff from school.
Maybe we should find a different train station.
We walk past this temple every day, Karen --
It's amazing. You're like this infinite storehouse of wisdom. Or trivia. I'm not sure which.
Nothing. I just -- I like that about you. You seem to be able to remember everything that's really important.
Your boss told me what happened.
I talked to your teachers. They said you can take as much time as you need. We could go to Kyoto for a weekend, see those temples you're always talking about.
There's nothing to run away from, Kat. No one blames you for what happened.
You went to help someone who was, quite simply, beyond help.
Don't beat yourself up searching for a greater truth, Kat. An old woman passed away in her sleep.
I'm sorry this happened to you.
I got us a guidebook to Kyoto. I thought maybe we'd leave tomorrow --
You were recovering from a shock.
Look, I'm sorry. I was just worried about you, and -- I know you, Karen.
So you think the events are connected?
Okay. How about this: the American family knew about what had happened there before, and this knowledge subconsciously caused them to repeat the same events.
It's exactly how superstitions survive: if you walk under a ladder and think uh-oh, you're in for some bad luck, sure enough, what do you know? You trip over --
You watched a woman die, Kat.
You just need to rest. We'll get you home, get a good night's sleep.
How can I believe you, Karen?
I'm concerned about you going out while you're so upset --
I'll never get used to this.
A public display of affection is considered rude in Japan.
Yeah, but I've never seen this before.
It's a Buddhist ritual. The incense smoke carries the prayers to the spirits of his ancestors, to help them remain at peace.
It's not trivia. It's what they believe. And it's far better, by the way, than your little pollution ritual.
Uh-uh. Seven years of bad luck.
I'll call you when I get home.
I just came by to pick up some books I left here. I'm not scheduled to work today --
Just a test to study for.   Why?
Oh my God... are you alright? --
Okay, Emma. Let's try again: my name is Karen. Do you remember?
Looks like you need a new Band-Aid.
How did you get up there?
Emma, who were you talking to?
You should get some rest, Emma.
I'm not even sure what did happen.
No, that's not what I mean...
Is that how they said she died?
I don't think I'll ever be ready for something like that.
Why don't you find out when I can check out of here.
Three months. I needed a social welfare credit.
I don't think so. I think it belonged to a woman.
I left it on the kitchen table.
This is him. This is the boy.
The whole time I was in that house, I felt something was... wrong.
About the bodies they found in the attic.
The same thing happened three years ago, Doug. To a Japanese family, who lived in that house. They were all found dead.
-- trip over the curb and sprain your ankle.
Okay. Then explain this: when I went to that house, I didn't know anything about its past. But yet I still saw...
Emma and I were alone in that room, but -- there was something else there. I'm sure of it.
You might be right, Doug. But I know what I saw.
You've got class, and I'm sure I only have to fill out a few forms or something --
That's the boy who was there yesterday. In that house. But this boy, he's --
I saw him, Doug. I talked to him.
There's something wrong with that house, Doug. Something really bad.
You don't understand.   I have to, Doug.
Because I've been inside that house, Doug. Don't you get it?
I love you. But I have to go.
My name is Karen Davies. I'm a student at -- I'm sorry to bother you, but I was wondering if I could ask you a few questions.
I'm here because... I need to speak with you about your husband.
I just need a couple minutes.
Your husband, Peter.    Three years ago he...
I think there's a connection between your husband's death and something that happened to me.
Look, I know this sounds strange, but... I don't think your husband wanted to die.
If that's true, then why are you still here in Japan?
Did you know a woman named Kayako?
Maybe it was someone he worked with?
Please. I don't know what else to do. Please help me.
Yes, I have important information for him about a case...
I know. But are you free?    Do you have class?
It's Yoko's case, but she didn't show up for work this morning, and I can't reach her at home. She must be sick, or something. And she has the damn house key.
"Mild dementia with severe lethargy." Apparently she sleeps through most of the day. Her daughter-in-law doesn't work, so she'll probably be there.
You're the one who's been bugging me about getting out there on your own. Besides, it's an English-only house.
Here's the address. Use the wall chart if you need help -- and don't forget to bring a map.
Matthew Williams, and his wife Jennifer. He's Emma's son, the woman Karen came here to see.
I met them when they came to register. It's standard procedure, though the visits were arranged by his employer. He works at --
Karen was a substitute -- Yoko is the girl who is normally in charge of Emma. She's also been missing from work.
I think I saw her bike outside.
I just want her to leave me alone.
I wonder if Mom's okay. She's been sleeping ever since we got here.
I'm sorry, sweetheart. It was probably just the move -- I'm sure she'll get back on schedule.
Maybe you should say something to the helper, what's her name?
Who knows? Maybe there's something she can suggest.
I miss seeing this every morning.
This will get easier soon, for Mom, for all of us. I promise.
Or else I'll tell the company it's just not working out, and that we're going back to the States with or without my old job. They can get someone else to crunch their numbers.
But until then -- promise me you'll give it a good try, okay Jen?
I'll probably be home late, maybe around nine or so.
I have a big conference.    They usually run long.
Sorry I'm late, it took awhile to wrap things up.
Then he quickly rips open the Yellow Pages --
Who are you? What -- what are you doing here?
She went out. Something came up.
I'm sorry.     This is a bad time.
She doesn't love me... she never loved me...
you see the back room. It's perfect for Mom -- she won't have to deal with the stairs.
Her bed won't be here until next week, but we can put the mattress on the floor. What do you think?
I'm downstairs. What number are you again?
I told you, Matthew, you can sleep through anything.
I went for a walk yesterday. Just to explore. I got lost and couldn't find anyone who could speak English, who could help me.
I'll do the shopping. Just call me if you're going to be late.
If you need something, all you have to do is say so --
I thought you guys were gonna cook!
Hi, Mom.    How are you feeling?
I guess I came at a bad time, huh?
I'll give you guys one minute to finish whatever you're doing up there and get your butts down here.
Well, I warned you. Prepare to be emotionally scarred.
Matthew!   Don't scare me like that!
I hope she's not long.    I'm absolutely starving.
I knew it. You guys forgot to go shopping, didn't you?
Are you okay? What's going on?
This is Suzuki-san, he's the Real Estate broker.
He said: "welcome to Tokyo". And that you must be very important to your company for them to rent this place for you.
He says no one has lived in this house for three years.
C'mon, Mom. You know what the doctor said about stairs.
I don't know what you're up to, but this is not cool --
I am Detective Nakagawa. This is Detective Igarashi, my assistant.
She is very shaken. We would like her to stay in the hospital tonight, under evaluation.
When was the last time you saw him?
We've spoken with his employer.   He did not show up for work today.
If you could please come by tomorrow to make a statement, the address is there, at the bottom --
I'm sorry to disturb you, Miss Davies. I was wondering if you could answer some additional questions?
You said this was the first time you'd been in that house?
About the Japanese boy you said you saw there --
No, not yet. You said the boy had been taped into the closet?
Did it belong to the boy?
I didn't see any book on the table.
We found this in the room where...
The bodies of the son and daughter-
It seems that the son killed his wife, and then himself --
Please excuse me for a moment.
Emma?   It's Yoko.   I'm coming in.
Hi, Emma.    It's good to see you again.
I don't even know her. She says I used to tutor her, but I don't know who the hell she is.
Detective Nakagawa is not here right now. Can you tell me what case this is regarding?
Can you tell me your name, please?
Hey, Maria, it's me. Yeah, I'm still at school...
